ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to write a full movie, which was cool.
I learned about the film industry and the process of writing a screenplay.
A better sense of screenplay formatting and the decisions writers must make when adapting a work.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The syllabus of this course was really interesting and far ranging, but I felt like many of the assignments felt more like busywork than constructive methods of engagement with the material.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I absolutely would, especially if you're interested in screenwriting!
Yes! It is a lot of work though.

This course is a lot of work. You will be reading a book, reading a script, watching a movie, and submitting a beat sheet on the movie every week which feels excessive and often feels redundant. It will expose you to a lot of media you probably will not have seen before which is great, but the writing process of the screenplay itself is not especially scaffolded by the course. It's a good class to take if you need the deadlines and structure of a class to write a screenplay, but this isn't a course that I would take as a fifth or 'for fun' class if you're doing it for a grade.
